description:
11.175 nnedi
Deinterlace video using neural network edge directed interpolation.

This filter accepts the following options:

deint.description: Set which frames to deinterlace. Can be 'all' or 'interlaced'.

etype.description: Set which set of weights to use in the predictor. Can be one of the following: 'a, abs', 's, mse'.

field.description: Set mode of operation. Can be one of the following: 'af', 'a', 't', 'b', 'tf', 'bf'.

nns.description: Set the number of neurons in predictor neural network. Can be one of the following: 'n16', 'n32', 'n64', 'n128', 'n256'.

nsize.description: Set size of local neighborhood around each pixel, used by the predictor neural network. Can be one of the following: 's8x6', 's16x6', 's32x6', 's48x6', 's8x4', 's16x4', 's32x4'.

planes.description: Set which planes to process. By default, the filter processes all frames.

pscrn.description: Controls whether or not the prescreener neural network is used to decide which pixels should be processed by the predictor neural network and which can be handled by simple cubic interpolation. Can be one of the following: 'none', 'original', 'new', 'new2', 'new3'. Default is 'new'.

qual.description: Controls the number of different neural network predictions that are blended together to compute the final output value. Can be 'fast', 'default', or 'slow'.

weights.description: Mandatory option, without binary file filter cannot work. Currently file can be found here: https://github.com/dubhater/vapoursynth-nnedi3/blob/master/src/nnedi3_weights.bin

name: nnedi

parameters.description: Mandatory option, without binary file filter can not work. Currently file can be found here: https://github.com/dubhater/vapoursynth-nnedi3/blob/master/src/nnedi3_weights.bin
parameters.name: weights

parameters.description: Set which frames to deinterlace, by default it is all. Can be all or interlaced.
parameters.name: deint

parameters.description:
Set mode of operation.

Can be one of the following:

‘af’

Use frame flags, both fields.

‘a’

Use frame flags, single field.

‘t’

Use top field only.

‘b’

Use bottom field only.

‘tf’

Use both fields, top first.

‘bf’

Use both fields, bottom first.
parameters.name: field

parameters.description: Set which planes to process, by default filter process all frames.
parameters.name: planes

parameters.description:
Set size of local neighborhood around each pixel, used by the predictor neural network.

Can be one of the following:

‘s8x6’
‘s16x6’
‘s32x6’
‘s48x6’
‘s8x4’
‘s16x4’
‘s32x4’
parameters.name: nsize

parameters.description:
Set the number of neurons in predictor neural network. Can be one of the following:

‘n16’
‘n32’
‘n64’
‘n128’
‘n256’
parameters.name: nns

parameters.description: Controls the number of different neural network predictions that are blended together to compute the final output value. Can be fast, default or slow.
parameters.name: qual

parameters.description:
Set which set of weights to use in the predictor. Can be one of the following:

‘a, abs’

weights trained to minimize absolute error

‘s, mse’

weights trained to minimize squared error
parameters.name: etype

parameters.description:
Controls whether or not the prescreener neural network is used to decide which pixels should be processed by the predictor neural network and which can be handled by simple cubic interpolation. The prescreener is trained to know whether cubic interpolation will be sufficient for a pixel or whether it should be predicted by the predictor nn. The computational complexity of the prescreener nn is much less than that of the predictor nn. Since most pixels can be handled by cubic interpolation, using the prescreener generally results in much faster processing. The prescreener is pretty accurate, so the difference between using it and not using it is almost always unnoticeable.

Can be one of the following:

‘none’
‘original’
‘new’
‘new2’
‘new3’

Default is new.
parameters.name: pscrn

source:
11.175 nnedi

Deinterlace video using neural network edge directed interpolation.

This filter accepts the following options:

weights

Mandatory option, without binary file filter can not work. Currently file can be found here: https://github.com/dubhater/vapoursynth-nnedi3/blob/master/src/nnedi3_weights.bin

deint

Set which frames to deinterlace, by default it is all. Can be all or interlaced.

field

Set mode of operation.

Can be one of the following:

‘af’

Use frame flags, both fields.

‘a’

Use frame flags, single field.

‘t’

Use top field only.

‘b’

Use bottom field only.

‘tf’

Use both fields, top first.

‘bf’

Use both fields, bottom first.

planes

Set which planes to process, by default filter process all frames.

nsize

Set size of local neighborhood around each pixel, used by the predictor neural network.

Can be one of the following:

‘s8x6’
‘s16x6’
‘s32x6’
‘s48x6’
‘s8x4’
‘s16x4’
‘s32x4’
nns

Set the number of neurons in predictor neural network. Can be one of the following:

‘n16’
‘n32’
‘n64’
‘n128’
‘n256’
qual

Controls the number of different neural network predictions that are blended together to compute the final output value. Can be fast, default or slow.

etype

Set which set of weights to use in the predictor. Can be one of the following:

‘a, abs’

weights trained to minimize absolute error

‘s, mse’

weights trained to minimize squared error

pscrn

Controls whether or not the prescreener neural network is used to decide which pixels should be processed by the predictor neural network and which can be handled by simple cubic interpolation. The prescreener is trained to know whether cubic interpolation will be sufficient for a pixel or whether it should be predicted by the predictor nn. The computational complexity of the prescreener nn is much less than that of the predictor nn. Since most pixels can be handled by cubic interpolation, using the prescreener generally results in much faster processing. The prescreener is pretty accurate, so the difference between using it and not using it is almost always unnoticeable.

Can be one of the following:

‘none’
‘original’
‘new’
‘new2’
‘new3’

Default is new.
